content.title: Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN) / Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (CI-AKI)
content.definition: Acute decline in renal function occurring within 48-72 hours of intravascular contrast administration, defined as increase in serum creatinine ≥0.5 mg/dL or ≥25% from baseline. Common complication of angiography and CTA with significant morbidity implications.

key_concepts.description: Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.5 mg/dL (or ≥25% relative increase) within 48-72 hours of contrast exposure in absence of other causes of AKI
Contrast causes renal vasoconstriction → medullary hypoxia; direct tubular toxicity; oxidative stress; osmotic effects. Combination leads to acute tubular necrosis
Pre-existing CKD (strongest risk factor); diabetes (especially with CKD); heart failure; volume depletion; high contrast volume; repeat contrast exposure; nephrotoxic drugs (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides)
Higher volume = higher risk; rule of thumb: contrast volume (mL) should not exceed 5 × body weight (kg) ÷ creatinine. Minimize volume; use dilute contrast
Iso-osmolar (Iodixanol/Visipaque) and low-osmolar (Iopamidol, Iohexol) are safer than high-osmolar contrast; iso-osmolar may be preferred in high-risk patients
IV normal saline (1 mL/kg/hr for 6-12 hours before and after) is the best-proven preventive measure; oral hydration less effective
NAC 600-1200mg PO BID before and after contrast has been used; evidence is mixed/weak; inexpensive and low risk so often given
Some studies suggest benefit of bicarbonate infusion over saline; evidence inconsistent; reasonable alternative if concerned about acidosis
Hold metformin before and 48 hours after contrast (lactic acidosis risk if AKI develops); hold NSAIDs; use caution with ACE inhibitors/ARBs
Usually reversible with peak creatinine at 3-5 days, recovery by 7-10 days; however, increased risk of long-term CKD progression, dialysis, and mortality

learning_objectives: Define CI-AKI and identify high-risk patients
Know the best preventive strategy (IV hydration)
clinical_pearls: CKD is the strongest risk factor - know baseline creatinine
IV normal saline is the best-proven prevention
Rule of thumb: contrast mL < 5 × weight(kg) ÷ creatinine
Creatinine peaks at 3-5 days, usually recovers by 7-10 days
Hold metformin 48 hours post-contrast (lactic acidosis if AKI)
NAC is cheap and low-risk, but evidence is weak
common_mistakes: Not checking baseline renal function before contrast
Confusing CIN (48-72h onset) with cholesterol embolization (delayed, persistent)
